name: Rock Creek (Upper North Fork, South Cascades)
description:
The upper northern fork of the more famous Rock Creek. This fork drains the southern slopes of Mowich Butte. With a smaller watershed, this fork sports lower flow and is open for business much earlier in the season. The flow on this section of Rock Creek seems to drop out pretty early -- you can often run it far earlier than other creeks in the vicinity. It may not be worth your time after April or so.

The Upper North Fork of Rock Creek sports three tributaries which all have waterfalls. The best bit, however, is the main line below the confluence. These falls are often visited by waterfall photographers, so please use dull, natural-colored webbing (or black) for anchors.

  • Watershed: 0.88mi^2.

Approach

Google Terrain maps show the "Sunset-Hemlock Rd" (FR 41) running along the crest - but this road has been closed and pretty much obliterated by Washington State DNR with berms every 20ft. Getting a car in there is not feasible, making the PCT the only viable approach to this creek.

Directions

From the Bridge of the Gods, turn right on Hwy 14 and continue 1.5mi east to turn off left/north towards Skamania Lodge on Rock Creek Dr. Turn left again in 0.3mi onto SW Foster Creek Rd. Continue 0.4mi and continue straight onto SW Ryan Allen Rd for another 0.5mi before turning left again onto Red Bluff Rd (becomes gravel). Follow Red Bluff Rd for 5.7mi to a bridge across Rock Creek. (Steep Creek Falls is just upstream / left of the bridge.) Continue west on Red Bluff Rd for 1.5mi to a junction where the main road swings left to cross a bridge over Rock Creek. Continue up the main road for another 0.8mi and turn right at an unsigned junction (Jct 1380). Follow this unnamed road for 0.5mi, passing a campsite near a creek at the bottom. On heading up the hill, watch for the crossing of the PCT and continue 200ft to a large pullout with room for several vehicles on the left. Roads are rocky but 2WD okay if driven carefully.

Hike In

From the parking area, follow the well maintained PCT north for about 1.75mi. At this point the trail crosses the western tributary just above R3. Options:

  • Drop directly into the western tributary from here.
  • Continue on up the switchbacks another 0.25mi and enter the western tributary higher up.

Descent

West Tributary

Leave the PCT at the end of a switchback at about 2350' elevation. Head directly west and drop down into the tributary (2min). This tributary seems to sport pretty low water and likely dries up entirely by the end of the summer.

  • R1: 50ft. Two stage. Low angle ramp which then swings DCL and drops down a second ramp to a small pool. Beware pendulum potential.
  • R2: 12ft drop into mini-narrows. Pass through 20ft long bedrock corridor to another slide falls (~20ft). No good anchors in the corridor, so anchored off large tree DCL at top of short drop. Need about 100ft of rope (SRT) per the horizontal distance.

Head down a moderately overgrown stream about 2min to reach the PCT. R3 is immediately below the trail.

  • R3: 25ft. Retrievable anchor recommended per proximity to the trail.

Head downstream wherever is easiest to reach the main fork. Staying in the creek was quite brushy when visiting in July 2016. In some places it was easier to hop out and hike down the adjacent bank wherever was easiest. On reaching the confluence, head downstream.

Upper North Fork

This segment is the best bit:

  • R4: North Fork Rock Creek Falls. 25ft. Can be bypassed DCR.
  • R5: 30ft falls over shelf of columnar basalt. Photogenic.

About 5-10min downstream, encounter a low-angle waterslide into a chest-deep pool. Easily downclimbed.

  • R6: 20ft falls over stair-step shelf. Possible swimmer in high water.
  • R7: 35ft. Calf-deep pool on landing. Watch for sharp edges on the lip.

Exit

Exiting DCR directly after R7 is feasible, but very steep / strenuous. Instead continue downstream another 5min to the confluence with the Lower North Fork. Just before the confluence, look for an animal trail DCR that provides an easy means of access up onto a spur ridge west of the creek. Once atop the ridge go directly up a steep brushy slope to reach the PCT. The steep slope is easily overcome, taking all of about 2min of thrashing. Once back on the trail, hike south ~1mi back to your car.

Red tape

None.

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

Northwest Waterfall Survey

Background

Creek was first descended by Kevin Clark and Kaitlin Rupert in July 2016.

The center and eastern tributaries on the Upper North Fork have been explored. Central tributary: 3 falls, but very low water and very brushy. Eastern tributary: 1 falls, but a long stream walk down to the main stem. Both of these options are probably not worth your time.
